newsitem.title: NETHERLANDS: MARTINAIR DOUBLES SOUTH AFRICAN FLIGHTS.
newsitem.headline: MARTINAIR DOUBLES SOUTH AFRICAN FLIGHTS.

text.p: Dutch cargo and charter airline, Martinair NV, is already increasing its South Africa flights, after only a month of operating the Amsterdam-
Johannesburg route, a Martinair spokesman said.
As of November 1, Martinair will fly twice-weekly into South Africa with a Boeing 747 freighter. The Dutch carrier began its operations to Johannesburg in the beginning of October.
This twice-weekly service will route via Harare on the return journey, he said.
Initially, the Dutch carrier obtained an NV3 permit to fly to South Africa, which means it had to carry 90 percent perishables cargo ex-Johannesburg, according to the South African government.
However, as the carrier now also flies via Harare it can pick-up other cargoes, as well as perishables, said the spokesman.
Martinair will also be flying four-times-a-week from Amsterdam to Nairobi from November 1. Last year, under its winter schedule, the carrier flew Sao Paulo to Nairobi and then returned to Amsterdam.
The new service will be direct Amsterdam-Nairobi. It will be operated twice weekly with an MD-11 and the other two services could be with an MD-11 or B747, said the spokesman.
Martinair if jointly-owned by KLM, the national Dutch airline, and Dutch shipping line, Nedlloyd.
